Meatballs: 2 slices of sandwich bread (without the crust)

instructions: The first two steps can and should be prepared at the same time.
- On a pot, put a tiny bit of oil with the tomatoes cut in half, cover and place on a low-medium heat.
- After some minutes the tomatoes are soft and they are to be mashed with a fork, and left cooking on low.
- To a beaten egg add pepper, (quite a bit of) salt, a minced clove of garlic, mix well and add the meat. Shred the bread, slightly soak in milk and mix in with the rest.
- Add the 2 tbsp of oil on a pan and start heating on medium.
- Using the measure of your choice (i.e. a spoon) make evenly sized meatballs, cover in flour (shake the extra flour) and brown them on at least 2 sides.
- When they are done, add them to the tomato sauce, which by now can be turned off. Also remove any chunks left in the oil.
- Deglaze the pan with a very tiny splash of the wine.
- Add the finely chopped onions, brown them. Sweetness is often an issue in this recipe and depends on the tomatoes, onion browning and if you decide to correct with sugar.
- Add salt, finely chopped garlic, sliced carrots and cook on medium heat for at least 10-12'.
- Pour in the wine, wait until it evaporates completely and turn the heat off. Now move everything to the pot.
- Pour water until the meatballs are almost submerged, add a tsp of paprika, the bay leaf, a dusting of thyme and leave for 45'-1h on low-medium heat, half-covered.
- Correct for salt mid way, and check there is enough sauce or else add water.
variants: I read once about an Italian grandma who added 1 or 2 seedless raisins to each meatball. I simply add them to the mix after soaking them in water for a few minutes.
To improve thickness and texture, adding about 4 cashews to the tomato sauce helps. Remove them after a while, blend them very finely with a bit of water and pour it back in.
